title-group.article-title: An Original Endoluminal Magnetic Anastomotic Device Allowing Pure NOTES Transgastric and Transrectal Sigmoidectomy in a Porcine Model
title-group.subtitle: Proof of Concept

article-meta.aff: 1IRCAD/EITS Institute, University Hospital of Strasbourg, Strasbourg, France
3University of California, San Francisco, CA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Joël Leroy, Department of Surgery, IRCAD/EITS, Hôpitaux Universitaires, 1 Place de l’Hôpital, 67091 Strasbourg Cedex, France Email: joel.leroy@ircad.u-strasbg.fr

abstract.p: Introduction. While experimental natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery (NOTES) sigmoid colectomies have been reported, pure NOTES anastomoses are restricted by the limited reach of commercially available circular staplers. MAGNAMOSIS is a set of self-orienting magnetic rings that can be delivered endoluminally throughout the colon to generate a compression anastomosis. Aim. To assess the feasibility of a pure NOTES transrectal (TR) and transgastric (TG) approach to perform any segmental colectomy. Materials and Methods. One pig (50 kg) underwent the experimental procedure as follows: (a) creation of the TG access to the peritoneal cavity, (b) precise transluminal placement of the proximal MAGNAMOSIS ring, (c) creation of the TR access with the TEO and transrectal dissection of the sigmoid mesentery, (d) resection of the surgical specimen, (e) transrectal extraction of the specimen, (f) delivery and mating of the distal MAGNAMOSIS ring, and (g) closure of the TG and TR viscerotomies. The animal survived for 14 days at which time burst pressure and histology were performed. Results. A pure NOTES TR and TG segmental colectomy was performed in 139 minutes. The postoperative course was uneventful. The animal had a formed bowel movement including the magnetic rings on postoperative day 5. Endoscopic examination at postoperative day 14 revealed a patent anastomosis. Necropsy revealed no abscess or signs of peritonitis. Burst pressure was >198 mm Hg. The histology showed a sealed anastomosis with mild inflammation. Conclusions. MAGNAMOSIS enabled a totally NOTES partial colectomy with combined TG and TR access. The flexible delivery options and low cost of manufacturing could make MAGNAMOSIS an attractive alternative to circular staplers.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery (NOTES) is an emerging technique in the evolution of minimal invasive surgery that combines endoscopic and surgical skills. The goal of NOTES is to produce safe and effective surgical interventions via instruments passed through a natural orifice. This technique eliminates external incision and their related morbidity including incisional pain, infection, and hernia.1

Transrectal access is ideal to perform NOTES colonic resections with a direct access to the target organ and the opportunity for natural orifice specimen extraction. Whiteford et al2 demonstrated in 2007 the feasibility of pure NOTES transrectal sigmoidectomy on 3 cadaveric models using the transanal endoscopic microsurgery (TEM; Richard Wolf Medical Instruments, Vernon Hills, IL) surgical platform. The sigmoid colon was delivered transanally, and the stapler anvil was sutured extracorporeally into the proximal colon using a standard purse-string suture with the suture tail left long for later manipulation and connection to the EEA stapler handle.

Our approach to pure NOTES sigmoidectomy was initially with a double access (transgastric and transrectal) in a survival swine model3: mesentery dissection and sigmoid division were achieved transrectally, while distal section, including the transrectal viscerotomy, and anastomosis construction were done after a “pull through” technique.

The next step we developed was the percutaneous endoluminal colonic anvil control (PECAC) technique4 to ease the positioning of the proximal anvil in virtually all the colon segments to be resected (a) to avoid opening the bowel intraperitoneally or (b) to exteriorise the proximal stump to accommodate the anvil extracorporeally. At this stage, we still had to use a Berci needle passed through the abdominal wall to manipulate the anvil intracorporeally and connect it to the stapler handle. However, NOTES purists rightly criticized the technique saying, “Not even a needle is allowed through the abdominal wall.”

The level of anastomosis in prior NOTES techniques was constrained by the limited reach of commercially available circular staplers. The techniques were limited to rectosigmoid resections and cannot be translated to other segmental colon resections. Potential solutions to overcome this limitation are circular staplers mounted over a flexible scope5 or endoscopically delivered anastomotic devices.

MAGNAMOSIS is a device for compression bowel anastomoses composed of two 23-mm diameter self-orienting magnetic rings with a circumferential groove that enables entrapment with an endoscopic snare (Figure 1).

caption.p: MAGNAMOSIS is a set of self-orienting magnetic rings that generate compression anastomosis.

sec.p: The rings generate a compression anastomosis by applying constant force on the interposed tissue leading to transmural ischemia, necrosis scarring, and full-thickness anastomosis formation. The MAGNAMOSIS design creates a unique compression gradient between the rings, which has proven superior to flat magnetic rings in the consistency of the anastomosis and the time to patency.6 The MAGNAMOSIS system has been studied in a series of publications that have shown the (a) ability of the system to create reliable full-thickness small bowel anastomoses when compared with both suture and stapled anastomoses, (b) the ability to be delivered with minimally invasive techniques, and (c) the ability to be immediately patent by opening the tissue within the inner rings.7

The aim of this study is to assess the feasibility of a full NOTES transgastric and transrectal segmental colectomy with a magnetic colonic anastomosis using transanal endoscopic operation (TEO) as surgical platform and the MAGNAMOSIS magnetic anastomotic device.

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: The animal used in our experimental laboratory was managed according to the French laws for animal use and care and to the directives of the European Community Council (Directive No. 86/609/EEC) under local ethics committee approval. The study was performed on 1 adult healthy pig (50 kg). The animal was fasted for 48 hours before surgery. Premedication by intramuscular injection of ketamine (7 mL) and azaperone (3 mL; Stresnil; Janssen-Cilag, Belgium) was administered 1 hour before surgery. Induction was achieved by intravenous propofol (10 mL/30 kg) combined with pancuronium (2 mL). Anesthesia was maintained with 2% isoflurane. Rectal enema was performed under anesthesia prior to the procedure.

sec.title: Step 1: Transgastric approach to the peritoneal cavity
sec.p: A double-channel video gastroscope (Karl Storz, Tüttlingen, Germany) was inserted perorally into the stomach. The gastrotomy site was chosen with transabdominal illumination, and a 1-cm-long incision on the anterior gastric body was performed with a monopolar energy needle-knife (Microvasive needle-knife RX; Boston Scientific Inc, Natick, MA). A dilating balloon catheter (Controlled Radial Expansion, CRE; Boston Scientific, Co Tipperary, Ireland) was inserted into the incision and inflated to dilate the gastrotomy. The balloon was then advanced into the peritoneum with limited visualization through the balloon wall to provide a safe and atraumatic entry. Carbon dioxide (CO2) low pressure (12 mm Hg) pneumoperitoneum was achieved through a custom gastroscope insufflator.

sec.title: Step 2: Delivery and control of the proximal magnet (Figure 2)
sec.p: The PECAC technique4 was modified to a transluminal endoscopic magnetic anvil control (TEMAC; Figure 2) technique for precise placement of the proximal magnetic ring. The site of proximal ring placement in the upper sigmoid colon was chosen and a double-channel video colonoscope (Karl Storz; Tüttlingen, Germany) was delivered to the site transanally. A rigid metallic guide wire (Visiglide; Olympus, Canterbury, New Zealand) was used to perforate the colon wall. The wire was visualized and grasped by the gastroscope to be exteriorized transorally. A MAGNAMOSIS ring was attached to anal end of the guide wire and delivered into the colon by pulling on the transoral end. An external magnet through the abdominal wall was used to control the position of the MAGNAMOSIS and facilitate retraction of the colonic mesentery.

sec.title: Step 3: Creation of the transrectal access, sigmoid colon mesentery dissection, specimen resection (Figure 3)
sec.p: The pig was placed in a steep Trendelenburg position, and the TEO device (Karl Storz) was inserted transrectally. A CO2 pneumorectum of 8 mm Hg was created, while the pneumoperitoneum was lowered to 4 mm Hg to facilitate rectal insufflation. A full-thickness 1-cm incision was made in the posterior rectal wall approximately 10 cm from the anal verge using 5-mm scissors with monopolar cautery (Mini-Shears Roticulator, Autosuture). Under TEO control, a 20-cm long and 1-cm diameter flexible plastic tube was inserted and passed through the rectal defect into the abdominal cavity as a trocar for further dissecting instruments. To achieve exposure and traction on the colonic mesentery, an external magnet was applied to the abdominal wall to manipulate the proximal MAGNAMOSIS ring.8,9

caption.p: Creation of the transrectal access, sigmoid colon mesentery dissection, and specimen resection

sec.p: Dissection was accomplished using roticulating scissors (Mini-Shears Roticulator, Autosuture) to make windows in the mesentery and the LigaSure-Advance (Covidien, Boulder, CO) to achieve the vascular control. The plastic tube serving as a port for dissecting instruments was replaced by a long 12-mm port (Versaport V2 Autosuture) to accommodate a linear stapler. The proximal transection was performed with an EndoGIA 45-mm blue cartridge (Covidien, Norwalk, CT) just below the proximal MAGNAMOSIS. The distal transection was then subsequently divided with the same linear stapler. The specimen was extracted through the rectum.

sec.title: Step 4: Delivery of distal MAGNAMOSIS ring and anastomosis construction (Figure 4)
sec.p: The distal MAGNAMOSIS ring was delivered using a customized system. The Ligasure Advance was covered with a protective soft rubber tube and advanced to the distal stump of the colon. The distal stump was perforated with the tip of the Ligasure Advance cautery tip, and the suture of the proximal magnet was grasped between the jaws. The distal magnet had been preloaded on the customized delivery system and was delivered to the distal stump. Traction on the suture of the proximal magnet brings the 2 rings together, and once within 2 cm, the rings self-orient and mate through magnetic force.

caption.p: Delivery of the distal MAGNOMOSIS and construction of the anastomosis

sec.title: Step 5: Closure of the transrectal access
sec.p: The viscerotomy was closed by interrupted 2.0 Maxon (Covidien) sutures using standard TEO techniques.

sec.title: Step 6: Establishment of immediate patency
sec.p: A full-thickness “double donut” of colon within the inner rings of the magnets was cut using the endoscopic needle-knife to establish immediate patency. The proximal colon was occluded and a leak test performed.

sec.title: Step 7: Closure of the transgastric access
sec.p: Transgastric viscerotomy was closed with endoscopic clips (Olympus, Tokyo, Japan).
Burst pressure and histology were performed on the excised anastomosis at postoperative day 14.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The total operative time was 139 minutes. Transgastric and transrectal accesses were created in 8 and 20 minutes, respectively. There were no intraoperative complications. Air and betadine leak tests were negative. Intraoperative endoscopic check confirmed correct closure of transrectal and gastric viscerotomy. At clinical follow-up, the pig presented no signs of distress and no changes in alimentary pattern and had a formed bowel movement including the magnetic rings on postoperative day 5.

Endoscopic examination at postoperative day 14 revealed a well-healed and fully patent anastomosis (Figure 5). Necropsy revealed a well-healed anastomosis with no leak, abscess, or signs of peritonitis. There were moderate adhesions between the region of the anastomosis and the fallopian tubes that were easily divided. Burst pressure of the anastomosis was >198 mm Hg, at which pressure the linear staple line used to resect the specimen burst. The histology showed a complete sealed anastomosis with mild inflammation of the mucosa and a mild fibrotic reaction (Figure 6).

caption.p: Postoperative day 14 endoscopy showed a patent anastomosis with a thin fibrotic ring without inflammatory reaction

The histological analysis at the anastomotic site shows a focal mild mucosal ulceration, a mild fibrosis, and chronic inflammation in the muscularis propria and a fibrosis without inflammation in the subserosal layer

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The current available technology does not meet the needs for pure NOTES, especially in procedures that require stapling lines and anastomosis. The SAGES/ASGE Working Group on NOTES called for the development of enabling technology to move the concept ahead, including for specially designed anastomotic devices10 permitting an endoscopic delivery.

Numerous attempts to create a “sutureless” bowel–bowel anastomosis have been performed.11 Stapling devices are actually extensively used in colorectal, bariatric, and esophageal surgery, especially since the advent of laparoscopy with comparable results to the hand-sewn anastomosis in terms of anastomotic leak rate but higher rate of strictures.12

Compression anastomosis was first described by Denan in 1826 and later popularized in 1892 with the Murphy Button, which is composed of metal rings that screw together to generate a compressive force.13-16 The Valtrac (Covidien, Norwalk, CT) is an evolution in compression anastomosis that used biofragmentable rings. It is approved for use in the United States and Europe and in multiple human trials has shown comparable rates of leak and stenosis to hand-sewn and stapled anastomoses for colorectal surgery.17-19

Human experience with colorectal magnetic anastomoses dates back to the 1980s in which magnetic rings were used to form the inner mucosal to mucosal anastomosis and the outer serosal layer was hand sewn.20 In a follow-up series of 21 patients, patency took between 7 and 12 days, and 2 leaks were reported.21 Further development of the device stopped due, in part, to prolonged time to patency.

The MAGNAMOSIS anastomotic device is a promising technology that enables a precise endoscopic control of the anastomotic site, is easy to use on a flexible delivery platform, and is cost-effective compared with staplers. Using the PECAC or our TEMAC technique, it can be precisely placed in virtually all the segments of the digestive tract.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: MAGNAMOSIS enabled a totally NOTES partial colectomy with a combined transgastric and transrectal access. The flexible delivery options and low cost of manufacturing could make MAGNAMOSIS an attractive alternative to circular staplers. The next step in translation of totally NOTES colonic resection with magnetic anastomosis to human use is the validation of the device on a large animal model and the standardization of the technique to show safety, efficacy, and reproducibility.

fn.p: The author(s) declared the following potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article:

Joël Leroy, Silvana Perretta, Michele Diana, Véronique Lindner, and Jacques Marescaux have no conflicts of interest or financial ties to disclose. Michael Harrison is the inventor of the device and shareholder in MIM, Inc, which holds the exclusive license to the device.
The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
